captions.text: <i>HE'S GONNA TAKE YOU BACK TO THE PAST</i>
<i>HE'S GONNA TAKE YOU BACK TO THE PAST</i>
<i>TO PLAY THE SHITTY GAMES THAT SUCK ASS</i>
<i>HE'D RATHER HAVE</i>
<i>A BUFFALO</i>
<i>TAKE A DIARRHEA DUMP IN HIS EAR</i>
<i>HE'D RATHER EAT</i>
<i>THE ROTTEN ASSHOLE</i>
<i>OF A ROADKILL SKUNK, AND DOWN IT WITH BEER</i>
<i>HE'S THE ANGRIEST GAMER YOU'VE EVER HEARD</i>
<i>HE'S THE ANGRY NINTENDO NERD</i>
<i>HE'S THE ANGRY ATARI, SEGA NERD</i>
<i>HE'S THE ANGRY VIDEO GAME NERD</i>
*Timing by Juanako25*
We've only touched upon some of the many classic gaming consoles, like the Atari 2600...
...but now, it's time to introduce you to two of its competitors.
<i>Feeling down and dirty, feeling kinda mean</i>
Exhibit A: The Intellivision.
<i>I've been from one to an another extreme</i>
Exhibit B: The Colecovision.
<i>This time I had a good time, ain't got time to wait</i>
Both tried to take down Atari, and both had a similar library of games.
<i>I wanna stick around 'till I can't see straight</i>
It's like today, you got all these games, you don't know which way to look!
<i>Fill my eyes with that double vision</i>
<i>No disguise for that double vision</i>
<i>Ooh, when it gets through to me, it's always new to me</i>
<i>A double vision's got the best of me</i>
First, we're gonna talk about the Intellivision. It was test marketed in 1979, but officially released in 1980.
Notice its fine wood texture. Everything back then was made of wood.
Do you know the Stone Age? Well, that was the Wood Age.
The Intellivision came from Mattel Electronics. Now, you know what else they made?
The Power Glove!
Now that's a bad sign right there. But, it was a great game system for its time.
Now, I'm gonna whip through a bunch of random games, mostly shitty ones...
...but I'm gonna tell you right now, I have three common complaints.
Number one: Many of the games are very similar to other games, and often, they're blatant copies.
Number two: Without instructions, they're difficult to understand how to play.
Number three: The controls suck ass!
And in this regard, the main problem is the controllers!
Why a numeric keypad? This is a video game controller, not a phone!

Then there's two little buttons on each side, which are usually the fire buttons.
It's awkward to handle!
And rather than a joystick, or a control pad of some kind, you get this weird disk!
Sometimes, in the heat of the game, you can actually jam your fingernail on it.
It also acts as a button, so in total, that's 17 buttons!
And for games this complex, you really need that many.
When you pop in a game, the first thing you do is to try every button before you figure out which ones do anything.
Most of them don't do jack shit, and it's different for each game.
Thet's why many of the games come with overlays. You slide it over the keys, and now you can see what they do.
It helps out, but damn, what a shitload of fuck.
And the games barely fit in the cartridge slot. It's like trying to stick your dick in a Cheerio.
So this is <i>Space Battle</i>. Sounds promising enough...
...but, okay, what's this? None of the buttons do anything but make fart noises.
And the overlay has a bunch of Triforces. Is this where they came from?
All you gotta to do is wait for the squadrons to meet the aliens...
...and then it brings up the battle screen, where you shoot blueberry pancakes.
*This* should be the whole game. Why does *this* part even exist?
Next, I don't know, let's try <i>Mission X</i>. More like Mission Ass.
It's a 2D shooter, but it's real hard to shoot things. I mean you have to be at the exact altitude.
2 rises up and 8 goes down, and the fire buttons are on the side.
I mean, that's great, right? Why not spread the buttons out as much as possible?
Alright, what's next? How about <i>Utopia</i>?
It's kind of a precursor to <i>Sim City</i>. You're basically the god of an island.
You build stuff, and storms come by, and... wow!
All I can say is that back in 1981 people had a lot more imagination.
Okay, how about <i>He-Man</i>? Oh man, I thought it was gonna be He-Man.
So you're flying around in the Wind Raider, shooting at stuff.
I think on the ground that's Skeletor. You drop bombs on him, and... that's it.
Wait, did I just call that white square a bomb? See? That's using your imagination.

<i>Vectron</i>! In the '80s, everything was Tron.
Megatron, Voltron, Tron the movie, you get the idea.
This is a weird, weird game. The first challenge is to figure out which of these indescribable objects you're controlling.
So, guess what? I think you're this green V. You can shoot at stuff, but you can't move!
And that's just fantastic, because there's a big gleaming box immediately blocking your path!
I'm not gonna lie: I don't get it.
Now, speaking of Tron, here we have <i>Tron Deadly Discs</i>.
You just run around, throwing shit at people.
Seems like it will be a fun little game, but what ruins it for me is how ass the controls are!
Rather than having one simple fire button, and aiming with the joypad, or disk, or whatever...
...the keypad determines which direction you shoot.
Shit the fuck!
<i>Thin Ice</i>! Okay, you're a penguin, ice-skating around, collecting torches...
...or they could be McDonald french fries, who knows.
The whole time, there's a seal on your ass, which kills you, but the black penguins do absolutely nothing.
<i>Advanced Dungeons & Dragons</i>. Well, advanced is right. For the time, it's a pretty complicated game.
You start out moving some dots around on a map screen...
...then you go into caves, you fight monsters, and find items.
What are those, jacks? Can I pick them up? I guess not.
The limited visibility is pretty annoying, and without the overlay or any instructions...
...I gotta admit I don't know what the hell I'm doing.
But, this is one of the grand-daddies of adventure games.
Alright, what've we got here? <i>Space Spartans</i>?
Man, what the hell does that mean? A Spartan in space?
Was Marvin the Martian a Space Spartan?
You're at this grid screen, and you shoot shit which looks like tie-fighters.
<i>Microsurgeon</i>!
The picture reminds me of Slim Goodbody. I can't believe I'm making that kind of reference...
But anyway, you control a barely visible dot on the screen, moving around the human body.
There's spiders and clouds floating around, and... I doubt this thing's medically accurate.
You just explore all the guts, technically making it the goriest game ever made.
But it only goes so far. Guess the piss and shit zone just didn't do it.
<i>Frog Bog</i>. You're a frog, and the goal is to eat as many flies as you can.
It's the same thing as <i>Frogs and Flies</i> on the Atari 2600, but the graphics are way better.
On Atari, the flies are just flickering dots. However, it's more fun to play because of its fluent control.
It's a fine example of better graphics don't make a better game.
<i>Buzz Bombers</i>! Now, this is fun. You kill a bunch of bees with bug spray.
But no, you don't use a can of bug spray, you ARE the can of bug spray.
There's also a hummingbird you can shoot at, but it doesn't seem to do anything.
You know when bees sting you, their asses breaks off and they die.
<i>Space Hawk</i>! Man, everything begins with <i>Space</i>.
So you're just a guy floating around in space, shooting green slime.
Oh-oh! Ah- the bubbles are coming! Gotta find the... Argh! Mother of a fuck!
It'd be so much easier to move, if you could just use the disk! Instead, it's the damn keypad!
Oh-oh! Here comes the space hawk! Gotta move! Gotta move! Damn!
I wipe my ass on this game!
<i>Boxing</i>.
Okay... yeah, boxing.
This sucks.
<i>Snafu.</i> You have to keep the line going as long as possible without touching other lines or hitting your own.
It's the bare basics of graphics, but surprisingly, it's a pretty fun game.
Okay. Now, we gotta move on, but let me introduce the <i>Intellivoice Voice Synthesis Module</i>.
What the fuck is that? Well, it makes your games talk.
Yeah. Now, at the time, the idea having voices in video games was a new thing.
But unfortunately, only a few games are compatible. Like <i>B-17 Bomber</i>.
*Mattel Electronics presents: B-17 Bomber*

- B-17 Bomber!
- *B-17 Bomber*
Alright, fuck the game, let's try <i>Bomb Squad</i>.
*Mattel Electronics presents: Bomb Squad*
*They'll never do it in time!*
*The code! The code! Figure out the code!*
What?
Guess I gotta defuse the bomb.
*It won't be easy! Replace this third, this fourth, this second, this first.
Oh shit! Oh shit!
Oh God!

title: Doublevision (Part 1) Intellivision - Angry Video Game Nerd - Episode 44
